zero.abs: solvte molecules move from higher solute concentration side to the lower

A.0: How can making tea relate to this experiment?
A.1: What are the basic ingredients you need to make tea?
A.2: Which equipment is similar to the ingredient you need in making tea?
A.3: U-tube with Water is essential in making tea. It is the first equipment you need.

S.0: Think about the relations to making tea.
S.1: Think about the basic ingredients you need to make tea.
S.2: Think about the equipment that is similar to the ingredient you need in making tea.
S.3: U-tube with Water is essential in making tea. It is the first equipment you need.

I.0: How can molecules move from higher concentration to lower concentration?
I.1: How many different molecules are needed to have a difference in concentration?
I.2: Which equipment contains molecules in a liquid that can serve as a base?
I.3: Water molecules can serve as the base for diffusion. U-tube with Water is the first equipment you need.

R.0: Think about how molecules move from higher concentration to lower concentration.
R.1: Think about how many different molecules are needed to have a difference in concentration.
R.2: Think about which equipment contains molecules in a liquid that can serve as a base.
R.3: Water molecules can serve as the base for diffusion. U-tube with Water is the first equipment you need.

A.0: How can water turn into tea relate to this experiment?
A.1: In tea, diffusion occurs when tea leaves is added to water to turn into tea. How can this process be replicated in the experiement?
A.2: Which equipment is similar to the function of tea leaves?
A.3: Green/Red dye is comparable to tea leaves. It is added to water to become color water.

S.0: Think about the relations to how water turn into tea.
S.1: In tea, diffusion occurs when tea leaves is added to water to turn into tea. Think about how this process can be replicated in the experiement.
S.2: Think about which equipment is similar to the function of tea leaves.
S.3: Green/Red dye is comparable to tea leaves. It is added to water to become color water.

I.0: How can there be a  higher concentration of water molecule?
I.1: What can be added in water to create a concentration difference?
I.2: Which equipment allows the visual movement of molecules achieving uniform concentration to be seen?
I.3: Green/Red dye can be added to water to showcase a visual transformation of diffusion. The water and color dye will mix and become color water.

R.0: Think about how there is a higher concentration of water molecules.
R.1: Think about what can be added in water to create a concentration difference.
R.2: Think about which equipment allows the visual movement of molecules achieving uniform concentration to be seen.
R.3: Green/Red dye can be added to water to showcase a visual transformation of diffusion. The water and color dye will mix and become color water.

zero.con: plant root absorbing water from the soil
zero.abs: water molecules moving from low solute concentration side to the higher

A.0: Osmosis occurs between plant roots and the soil. What is the similarity to this experiment?
A.1: What does the roots absorb from the soil?
A.3: In osmosis, the plant roots absorb water from the soil! It is inside the beaker which is the first equipment you need!

S.0: Osmosis occurs between plant roots and the soil. Think about the similarity to this experiment.
S.1: Think about what does the roots absorb from the soil.
S.2: Think about which equipment contains this substance?
S.3: In osmosis, the plant roots absorb water from the soil! It is inside the beaker which is the first equipment you need!

I.0: How can the movement of solvent molecules move down the concentration gradient?
I.1: Osmosis involves solvent molecules. Which is that?
I.2: Select the most suitable equipment which can serve as base solvent and dissolve other substance?
I.3: Water is a solvent as it can dissovle other substance. It is inside the beaker which is the first equipment you need!

R.0: Think about the movement of solvent molecules move down the concentration gradient.
R.1: Osmosis invovles solvent molecules. Think about which is that.
R.2: Think about which equipment contains something that can serve as base solvent and dissolve other substance?
R.3: Water is a solvent as it can dissovle other substance. It is inside the beaker which is the first equipment you need!

utube.abs: block the free movement of solute molecule

A.0: How does a teabag turn into tea relate to this experiment?
A.1: The tea bag don't allow leaf move out the bag, so there is concentration difference.
A.2: Which equipment is similar to the teabag? It can block the big molecule movement.
A.3: A teabag is like a semi-permeable membrane! It only allows water to enter but blocks the tea leaves from leaving. This is the second equipment you need.

S.0: Consider the relations to how a teabag turn into tea.
S.1: Think about the tea bag don't allow leaf move out the bag, so there is concentration difference.
S.2: Think about which equipment can have the same function as the bag of tea, block the big molecule movement.
S.3: Semipermeable membrane can block the free movement of solute molecule, that's what you need.

I.0: What does osmosis need but diffusion do not?
I.1: Why can only solvent molecules move down a concentration gradient?
I.2: Which equipment can block free movement of solute molecules?
I.3: A semi-permeable membrane only allows certain molecules to pass through it! It is necessary in osmosis but not in diffusion. This is the second equipment you need.

R.0: Consider what does osmosis need but diffusion do not.
R.1: The solvent can move free in the beaker, how can block free movement of solute.
R.2: Consider which equipment allows selective movement of molecules.
R.3: Semipermeable membrane can block the free movement of solute molecule, that's what you need.

utubemembrane.con: placing a red blood cell in water causes it to burst

A.0: Why does placing a red blood cell in water causes it to burst?
A.1: Concentration difference of solute cause the red blood cell burst.
A.2: You need to select a suitable solute whcih can not go through semipermeable membrane, to produce concentration difference.
A.3: Salt molecules can not go through semipermeable membrane, it can cause concentration difference, that's what you need.

S.0: Think about the reason why placing a red blood cell in water causes it to burst.
S.1: Concentration difference of solute cause the red blood cell burst.
S.2: Think about which equipment can cause a difference in concentration of water.
S.3: Salt molecules can not go through semipermeable membrane, it can cause concentration difference, that's what you need.

I.0: Which molecules can not go though the semi-permeable membrane?
I.1: Which molecules cannot go though the semi-permeable membrane?
I.2: Which material will dissolve in the solvent?
I.3: Salt can dissolve in water, it can cause concentration difference, that's what you need.

R.0: Think about which molecules can not go though the semi-permeable membrane.
R.1: Think about which molecules cannot go though the semi-permeable membrane
R.2: Think about which material will dissolve in the solvent?
R.3: Salt can dissolve in water, it can cause concentration difference, that's what you need.
